Issues.Title: Modal close button variable ($modal-close-dimensions) does not change the size
Issues.Body:
This is about Bulma. Related to #2121 that is closed without solving.

### Overview of the problem
Using Bulma 0.7.4: setting the `$modal-close-dimensions` variable does not have the desired effect.

### Description
The button is limited by `max-width` and `max-height` to `20px` as the `.modal-close` class extends `%delete`, which has those settings. On top of that, the actual delete sign is just 50% wide, so in fact the variable is misleading.

### Steps to Reproduce
Set the `$modal-close-dimensions` variable to anything above 20px and the button will not change size.

### Expected behavior
The close button should have the variable set size. 

### Actual behavior
The close button size does cannot exceed 20px.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Modal close button variable ($modal-close-dimensions) does not change the size" (#2494)

Issues.Title: Feature Request: Rounded Textarea
Issues.Body:
This is about **Bulma**.

### Overview of the feature
This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**

I think for the sake of keeping a uniform look, the corner radius of textareas should appear to match that of same-sized inputs (most types of keyboard inputs, buttons, etc). Thus, if the typical height of an input[type='text'] is 1.25rem, then the corner radius might be: `(text-size + padding + margin + border-size) / 2` or something similar.

Just a thought/idea to ponder.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Feature Request: Rounded Textarea" (#2491)

Issues.Title: Rename breakpoints to make sense with custom values
Issues.Body:
This is about **Bulma**.

It is a feature/question.

### Overview of the problem

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
I'm using Bulma **version** 0.7.5

### Description

Would you be willing to change the breakpoint names? They currently only make sense if you use the default values. If someone was to change these default values, as I intend to, the names will no longer make sense. A more generic/less specific naming convention would allow people to redefine the breakpoints as they wish and it will still make sense.

A suggestion could be: `smallest`, `smaller`, `medium`, `larger`, `largest`
or the bootstrap way: `extra small (xs)`, `small (sm)`, `medium (md)`, `large (lg)`, `extra large (xl)`
or even just sequential: `breakpoint 1 (bp1)`, `breakpoint 2 (bp2)`, `breakpoint 3 (bp3)`, `breakpoint 4 (bp4)`, `breakpoint 5 (bp5)`
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Rename breakpoints to make sense with custom values" (#2485)

Issues.Title: Invalid output when declaring a custom shade map
Issues.Body:
This is about Bulma.

### Overview of the problem
When declaring a custom shade map, the colour helper functions for "has-background-{shade}" and "has-text-{shade}" outputs in an invalid css format. 

This issue was previously reported but has been subsequently closed without a fix.

### Description
Using Bulma 0.7.4, I am trying to define custom shades and add a color to it (i.e. fuchsia). I need to find a way for having the corresponding helper classes generated (.has-text-fuchsia .has-background-fuchsia).

### Steps to Reproduce
Add $fuchsia to $custom-shades, like so:

`$fuchsia: #d705a3`
`$custom-shades: ("fuchsia": $fuchsia);`

When I do that, Bulma first runs mergeColorMaps and then generates the classes, except the ones corresponding to $custom-shades are wrong, because findColorInvert is also called, which adds #fff as the default inverted color. 

This works without problems if I use $custom-colors (either specifying the inverted color or not).

### Expected behavior
The CSS output should be:

`.has-text-fuchsia {
    color: #d705a3 !important;
} `

### Actual behavior
The CSS output is:

`.has-text-fuchsia {
    color: #d705a3, #fff !important;
} `
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Invalid output when declaring a custom shade map" (#2483)

Issues.Title: Wrong breakpoint values in documentation
Issues.Body:
This is about the **Bulma Docs**.

### Overview of the problem

This is about the Bulma **Docs**
I'm using Bulma **version** 0.7.4
I am not sure this issue is **not a duplicate**

### Description
Following the documentation:

Bulma has 5 breakpoints:
* mobile: up to 768px
* tablet: from 769px
* desktop: from 1024px
* widescreen: from 1216px
* fullhd: from 1408px

But following the documentation:

   Name     |   Type   |    Default Value    | Value
----------- | -------- | ------------------- | ------
$gap        | size     | 64px                |
$tablet     | size     | 769px               |
$desktop    | computed | 960px + (2 * $gap)  | 1088px
$widescreen | computed | 1152px + (2 * $gap) | 1280px
$fullhd     | computed | 1344px + (2 * $gap) | 1472px

So I am sure that the document is not up to date.

### Expected behavior
The documentation should be:

Bulma has 5 breakpoints:
* mobile: up to 768px
* tablet: from 769px
* desktop: from 1088px
* widescreen: from 1280px
* fullhd: from 1472px
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Wrong breakpoint values in documentation" (#2472)

Issues.Title: [Question]: How to make NavBar float over content
Issues.Body:
This is about **Bulma**.

It is a question.

### Overview of the problem

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
I'm using Bulma **version** 0.7.4
My **browser** is: Chrome and Firefox
I have looked though all the nav bar issues but have not been able to see this issue addressed in them.

### Description

I have a standard nav bar with the burger menu. This is taken straight from the docs website.

I have managed to activate and deactivate the menu by clicking the burger menu. This is fairly straight forward.

My issue is that when the burger menu activates, it pushes the content out of the way. I would like it to float over the content.

Is there a simple Bulma idiomatic way to make this happen?

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Click the burger menu icons on any of the nav bars in this section: https://bulma.io/documentation/components/navbar/#colors
2. Note the content being pushed out of the way

### Expected behaviour

I would like the nav bar burger menu to float over the subsequent content.

### Actual behaviour

The burger menu does not float over the subsequent content but pushes it out of the way.
